HTTP Modules

Complete HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2 protocol implementation with client and server support. More...

Collaboration diagram for HTTP Modules:

Modules

 HPACK Header Compression Module
 
 HTTP/1.1 Parser and Serializer Module
 Comprehensive HTTP/1.1 parsing, serialization, and transfer encoding support.
 
 HTTP/2 Private Implementation Details
 
 HTTP/2 Protocol Implementation
 HTTP/2 (RFC 9113) support with framing, streams, flow control, and HPACK integration.
 
 HTTP Client Module
 High-level HTTP client library supporting HTTP/1.1, HTTP/2, connection pooling, async I/O, authentication, cookies, redirects, compression, and proxy support.
 
 HTTP Server Error Handling Macros
 Migration guide for deprecated HTTP server statistics macros.
 
 Internal HTTP Server Connection Management Helpers
 Helper functions for managing individual HTTP server connections.

#define http1_is_tchar(c)   SOCKETHTTP_IS_TCHAR (c)
 Determine if a byte is a valid HTTP token character (tchar).
 
#define http1_is_digit(c)   ((c) >= '0' && (c) <= '9')
 Check if a character is an ASCII decimal digit (0-9).
 
#define http1_is_hex(c)
 Test if a character is a valid hexadecimal digit (0-9, a-f, A-F).

 Convert a hexadecimal digit character to its integer value (0-15).
 
#define http1_is_ows(c)   ((c) == ' ' || (c) == '\t')
 Check if character is optional whitespace (OWS: SP or HTAB).
 
#define http1_is_vchar(c)    ((unsigned char)(c) >= 0x21 && (unsigned char)(c) <= 0x7E)
 Check if byte is a visible (non-control) US-ASCII character (VCHAR).
 
#define http1_is_obs_text(c)   ((unsigned char)(c) >= 0x80)
 Check if byte is obsolete text (high octet characters 0x80-0xFF).
 
#define http1_is_field_vchar(c)   (http1_is_vchar (c) || http1_is_obs_text (c))
 Check if character is valid in HTTP header field values (field-vchar).

Detailed Description

Complete HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2 protocol implementation with client and server support.

The HTTP group provides comprehensive HTTP protocol support including parsing, serialization, client/server implementations, and advanced features. Key components include:

  • SocketHTTP (core): HTTP types, headers, URI parsing, status codes (HTTP Modules)
  • SocketHTTP1: HTTP/1.1 parsing and serialization (HTTP/1.1 Module)
  • SocketHTTP2: HTTP/2 protocol implementation (HTTP/2 Module)
  • SocketHTTPClient: High-level HTTP client with pooling (HTTP Client Module)
  • SocketHTTPServer: HTTP server implementation (HTTP Server Module)
  • SocketHPACK: HTTP/2 header compression (HPACK Module)
See also
Core Foundation Modules for base infrastructure.
Core I/O Modules for socket primitives.
Security Modules for TLS integration.
SocketHTTPClient_T for HTTP client usage.
SocketHTTPServer_T for HTTP server implementation.

struct HPACK_DynamicEntry

Entry in the HPACK dynamic table storing a header field name-value pair.

◆ SocketHPACK_Table

struct SocketHPACK_Table

Dynamic table for storing header fields in HPACK compression (RFC 7541).

HPACK dynamic table (opaque type)

Implements a circular buffer (ring buffer) for efficient eviction of oldest entries. Indices follow HPACK convention: index 1 is most recent, increasing indices are older. Supports dynamic resizing based on SETTINGS_HEADER_TABLE_SIZE.

See also
HPACK_DynamicEntry for individual entries.
hpack_table_evict() for eviction mechanism.
SocketHPACK_Encoder::table and SocketHPACK_Decoder::table for usage.

◆ SocketHPACK_Decoder

struct SocketHPACK_Decoder

Internal structure for HPACK header decoder.

HPACK decoder (opaque type)

Handles decompression of HPACK-encoded headers with security checks against decompression bombs (excessive expansion). Used by SocketHTTP2 for processing incoming headers.

See also
SocketHPACK_DecoderConfig for configuration.
SocketHPACK_Table_T for dynamic table.
Warning
Decompression bomb protection limits ratio of output to input bytes.

◆ HPACK_StaticEntry

struct HPACK_StaticEntry

Structure for entries in the HPACK static table (RFC 7541 Table 2).

Contains 61 predefined HTTP header fields. Field order minimizes padding. Strings are compile-time constants, no allocation needed.

See also
hpack_static_table for the full array of entries.

◆ HPACK_HuffmanSymbol

struct HPACK_HuffmanSymbol

Entry in the HPACK Huffman encoding table for a specific symbol.

Maps a symbol (0-256) to its variable-length Huffman code. Code is left-aligned in 32-bit field for easy bit manipulation.

See also
hpack_huffman_encode for the full table.
RFC 7541 Appendix B for Huffman code assignment.

◆ HeaderEntry

struct HeaderEntry

Internal node structure used by SocketHTTP_Headers_T for storing individual headers in both hash table collision chains and insertion-order doubly-linked list.

◆ SocketHTTP_URI

struct SocketHTTP_URI

Parsed URI components according to RFC 3986.

Structure holding the generic syntax components of a URI or URI reference. All string pointers reference substrings from the original input or arena-allocated copies; they remain valid until the arena is cleared or disposed. Strings are null-terminated for convenience but lengths are provided for efficiency. Does not perform percent-decoding; use SocketHTTP_URI_decode() for that. Supports absolute URIs, origin form, and relative references. Host may include IPv6 literals in [brackets]; userinfo is parsed but deprecated per RFC 3986.

◆ SocketHTTP1_Parser

struct SocketHTTP1_Parser

Internal implementation structure for the HTTP/1.1 parser (SocketHTTP1_Parser_T).

HTTP/1.1 parser instance (opaque type)

Manages all aspects of incremental HTTP/1.1 message parsing: configuration, DFA state machine, message construction (request/response), header/trailer accumulation, token buffering, body handling (content-length, chunked, until-close), limits enforcement, and connection flags.

Memory: All dynamic allocations (buffers, headers) from the 'arena' member. Parsing: Advances via internal_state using DFA tables; high-level state tracks progress. Limits: Counters prevent DoS (e.g., too many headers, oversized lines). Body: Supports transfer-encoding: chunked (with trailers) or content-length. Flags: Determines keep-alive, upgrades (e.g., WebSocket), 100-continue expectations.

Field groups:

  • Configuration: mode, config, arena
  • Parser state: state, error, internal_state
  • Current message: message union (request or response)
  • Headers/Trailers: headers (main), trailers (chunked end)
  • Token buffers: method_buf, uri_buf, reason_buf, name_buf, value_buf
  • Counters: header_count, total_header_size, line_length, etc. (and trailers)
  • Body state: body_mode, content_length, body_remaining, body_complete
  • Chunked state: chunk_size, chunk_remaining
  • Parsed values: version_major/minor, status_code
  • Flags: keepalive, is_upgrade, upgrade_protocol, expects_continue
Note
Not thread-safe; single-threaded use only.
User must not access fields directly; use public API getters.
See also
SocketHTTP1_Parser_new() for creation with config.
SocketHTTP1_Parser_execute() for feeding data and advancing state.
SocketHTTP1_Parser_get_request(), SocketHTTP1_Parser_get_response() for results.
SocketHTTP_Request, SocketHTTP_Response for message details.
SocketHTTP_Headers_T for header handling.
HTTP1_TokenBuf for token accumulation.
HTTP1_InternalState for DFA states.
SocketHTTP1_Config for configurable limits and behavior.
RFC 7230 for HTTP/1.1 specification compliance details.

◆ SocketHTTP2_Conn

struct SocketHTTP2_Conn

Internal structure for HTTP/2 connection management.

HTTP/2 connection (opaque type)

Central state holder for an HTTP/2 connection: underlying socket, memory arena, role (client/server), HPACK encoder/decoder, I/O buffers, settings (local/peer), flow control, stream hash table with counts and rate limits, frame state (e.g., CONTINUATION, GOAWAY, PING), callbacks, timeouts, and DoS protections (RST/PING/ SETTINGS rate limiting per CVE-2023-44487 and similar).

Handles protocol compliance, security hardening, and event emission.

Note

◆ ServerConnection

struct ServerConnection

Core internal structure representing an active HTTP client connection.

Encapsulates all state for one client connection:

  • Socket handle and client address
  • Parsing and buffering (HTTP/1.1 parser, in/out buffers)
  • Request data (parsed request, body handling/streaming)
  • Response data (status, headers, body streaming)
  • Timing (creation, activity, request/response start times)
  • Metrics (request count, active streams for HTTP/2)
  • Resource tracking (memory used, arena)
  • Linked list pointers for server-wide connection management

State transitions managed via state field. Memory managed via arena; cleared on connection close. Thread-unsafe; accessed only from server event loop thread.

See also
connection_new() for allocation.
connection_close() for cleanup.
SocketHTTPServer::connections for list integration.
SocketHTTP_Request for parsed request details.
SocketHTTP1_Parser_T for HTTP/1.1 parsing state.

◆ SocketHTTPServer_Request

struct SocketHTTPServer_Request

Internal implementation details of the SocketHTTPServer_Request opaque type.

Opaque request context for handling individual HTTP requests.

This structure is passed to user-defined request handlers (SocketHTTPServer_Handler). It provides:

  • Reference to owning server for configuration and stats access
  • Underlying connection for low-level operations (internal use)
  • Per-request Arena_T for temporary allocations (freed after handler completes)
  • Start timestamp for latency calculations

Users MUST NOT access fields directly. Use public accessors like:

  • SocketHTTPServer_request_server()
  • SocketHTTPServer_request_arena()
  • SocketHTTPServer_request_time()
See also
SocketHTTPServer_Request in SocketHTTPServer.h for public opaque declaration.
SocketHTTPServer_Handler for usage in callbacks.
Arena_T for memory management details.

Contains parsed request details (method, URI, headers, body) and provides API for building responses (status, headers, body streaming). Lifetime scoped to the handler callback; do not store beyond callback execution. Memory managed by server arena.

See also
SocketHTTPServer_Handler callback usage.
SocketHTTPServer_Request_method(), SocketHTTPServer_Request_headers() etc.
SocketHTTPServer_Request_finish() to complete response.

◆ SocketHTTPServer

struct SocketHTTPServer

Internal implementation of the SocketHTTPServer opaque type.

Opaque HTTP server instance managing connections, requests, and protocol handling.

Central structure managing the entire HTTP server instance:

  • Configuration (config)
  • Listening socket and event poll (listen_socket, poll)
  • User callbacks for handling, validation, draining (handler, validator, drain_callback)
  • Connection list and counts (connections, connection_count)
  • Rate limiting configuration (rate_limiters, global_rate_limiter)
  • IP-based connection limiting (ip_tracker)
  • Graceful shutdown state (state, drain_start_ms, drain_timeout_ms)
  • Legacy stats fields (being phased out in favor of SocketMetrics)
  • Server arena for allocations

Thread-unsafe by design; intended for single-threaded use with SocketPoll. All access serialized by the event loop.

Note
Statistics and latency tracking migrated to SocketMetrics for centralized, thread-safe metrics. Legacy fields (stats_prev_requests, etc.) retained for compatibility but deprecated.
No embedded TLS; use SocketTLS integration via public API.
See also
SocketHTTPServer_new() for creation and initialization.
SocketHTTPServer_free() for cleanup and resource release.
SocketPoll_T for event loop integration details.
SocketIPTracker_T for client limiting implementation.
SocketRateLimit_T for rate limiting details.

Handles listening, accepting connections, parsing HTTP requests (1.1/2), invoking handlers, and sending responses. Integrates with SocketPoll for event-driven operation. Supports TLS, rate limiting, and graceful shutdown.

See also
SocketHTTPServer_new() for creation.
SocketHTTPServer_Config for configuration options.
SocketHTTPServer_process() for event processing.

int request_timeout_ms Idle timeout between requests in ms (default: 30s). Closes idle keep-alive connections after this period.
int response_write_timeout_ms Maximum time to send complete response in ms (default: 60s). Ensures timely response delivery; aborts on timeout.

◆ SocketHTTPServer_Stats

struct SocketHTTPServer_Stats

Comprehensive server statistics structure for monitoring and debugging.

Aggregates counters, gauges, and histograms for server health, performance, and error tracking. Updated atomically during operation; snapshot via SocketHTTPServer_stats(). Includes connections, requests, bytes, errors, timeouts, rate limits, and latency percentiles (us resolution).

Reset with SocketHTTPServer_stats_reset() (preserves active_connections). Use for logging, metrics export (Prometheus), or alerting.

See also
SocketHTTPServer_stats() to populate.
SocketMetrics for global library metrics.
SocketPool stats for connection pool details.

◆ HTTP1_DEFAULT_METHOD_BUF_SIZE

#define HTTP1_DEFAULT_METHOD_BUF_SIZE   16

Default initial capacities for HTTP/1.1 token buffers used in parsing.

Chosen to balance memory efficiency and common case performance:

  • Small for fixed-size tokens (methods, names)
  • Larger for variable (URIs, values) Buffers start at these sizes in http1_tokenbuf_init() and grow dynamically. Enforced against SocketHTTP1_Config limits during growth.
See also
HTTP1_TokenBuf for buffer management.
http1_tokenbuf_init() where these are passed as initial_capacity.
SocketHTTP1_Config::max_method_size, max_uri_size, etc. for runtime limits.

Default initial capacity for method token buffer (e.g., "GET", "POST").

◆ SOCKETHTTP_MAX_HEADER_NAME

#define SOCKETHTTP_MAX_HEADER_NAME   256

Maximum allowed length for HTTP header names, in bytes.

This configurable limit protects against denial-of-service attacks via excessively long header names. The default value of 256 bytes is sufficient for all standard HTTP headers (e.g., "Authorization", "Content-Type") and most custom headers.

Redefine before including SocketHTTP.h to adjust for specific needs, but keep conservative for security. Exceeding this during parsing raises SocketHTTP_Failed.

Note
Header names must also be valid tokens per RFC 9110 (tchar characters only).
See also
SocketHTTP_header_name_valid() for validation function.
SocketHTTP_MAX_HEADER_VALUE for value length limits.
SocketHTTP_MAX_HEADER_SIZE for total headers limit.

◆ SOCKETHTTP_MAX_HEADER_SIZE

#define SOCKETHTTP_MAX_HEADER_SIZE   (64 * 1024)

Maximum total size for all HTTP headers combined, in bytes.

Cumulative limit on header block size to mitigate DoS from many/small headers or few/large ones. Default 64 KiB is generous for typical requests but protects servers from abuse. Used in parsing to prevent excessive memory use.

Note
Enforced in header collection; exceeding raises SocketHTTP_Failed in parsers.

Limits single header values to prevent memory exhaustion or buffer overflows. Default 8 KiB accommodates large values like base64-encoded data in Authorization or cookies. Larger values may indicate attacks; adjust cautiously.

◆ SocketHTTPServer_BodyCallback

typedef int(* SocketHTTPServer_BodyCallback) (SocketHTTPServer_Request_T req, const void *chunk, size_t len, int is_final, void *userdata)

Callback for streaming request body data incrementally.

Enables memory-efficient handling of large request bodies (e.g., file uploads) by processing data in chunks as received, without loading the entire body into memory. To use, call SocketHTTPServer_Request_body_stream() in the handler before finishing. The server will then invoke this callback for each chunk parsed from the wire.

Parameters
reqRequest context (same as handler; use for response setup if needed).
chunkPointer to body data chunk (valid only during callback; do not store or free).
lenLength of the chunk in bytes.
is_finalNon-zero if this is the final chunk (end of body), zero otherwise.
userdataUser-provided data passed unchanged from SocketHTTPServer_Request_body_stream().
Returns
0 to continue receiving and processing more body chunks, non-zero to abort the request (server sends 400 Bad Request and closes connection).
Note
Chunks may arrive in any size up to internal buffer limits (typically 4-8KB).
For chunked encoding, is_final is set after final zero-length chunk.
Body data is temporary; copy if needed for later use (use request arena).
Thread-safety depends on server configuration; typically called from event thread.
Warning
Aborting mid-body closes the connection immediately; client may retry.
See also
SocketHTTPServer_Request_body_stream() to enable streaming mode.
SocketHTTPServer_Request_body_expected() for expected total length.
SocketHTTPServer_Request_is_chunked() for transfer encoding info.

Definition at line 477 of file SocketHTTPServer.h.

Callback notified when graceful drain (shutdown) completes.

Invoked by the server when the drain process finishes: either all active connections and requests have completed gracefully, or the timeout expired forcing closure of remaining connections. Useful for cleanup, logging, or signaling other services.

Parameters

timed_outNon-zero if drain timed out (remaining connections force-closed), zero if completed gracefully within timeout.
userdataUser data provided at callback registration.
Note
Called from the event loop thread during or after drain_poll().
Server is still valid but in STOPPED state; do not start it again.
If timed_out, some requests may have been aborted; check stats for details.
See also

◆ SocketHTTPServer_Handler

typedef void(* SocketHTTPServer_Handler) (SocketHTTPServer_Request_T req, void *userdata)

Primary request handler callback invoked for each incoming HTTP request.

This is the main entry point for application logic. For each parsed HTTP request, the server calls this callback with the request context. The handler is responsible for:

  1. Inspecting request via accessors: method, path, headers, body.
  2. Setting response: status with SocketHTTPServer_Request_status(), headers with SocketHTTPServer_Request_header().
  3. Providing body: either static with SocketHTTPServer_Request_body_data() or streaming with SocketHTTPServer_Request_begin_stream().
  4. Finalizing with SocketHTTPServer_Request_finish() or SocketHTTPServer_Request_end_stream().

The req context is valid only during callback execution. Do not store pointers to it or its contents beyond the callback; they may be invalidated or freed. All allocations use the per-request arena available via SocketHTTPServer_Request_arena().

Parameters
reqRequest context containing parsed request data and response builders.
userdataArbitrary user data set via SocketHTTPServer_set_handler().
Thread Safety\n No - invoked from server's event loop thread (SocketPoll integration).
Server instances should not be shared across threads without external sync.
Note
For WebSocket upgrades, check SocketHTTPServer_Request_is_websocket() and use SocketHTTPServer_Request_upgrade_websocket() instead of standard response.
For HTTP/2 push, use SocketHTTPServer_Request_push() if supported.
See also
SocketHTTPServer_set_handler() to register this callback.
SocketHTTPServer_Request_T for full request/response API.
SocketHTTP_Headers_T for header manipulation.
HTTP Module Group for protocol details.

Definition at line 446 of file SocketHTTPServer.h.

◆ SocketHTTPServer_Validator

typedef int(* SocketHTTPServer_Validator) (SocketHTTPServer_Request_T req, int *reject_status, void *userdata)

Middleware callback for request validation and authentication.

Executed before the main handler for every request. Ideal for common checks like authentication (e.g., API keys, JWT), authorization, rate limiting, CORS preflight, or input sanitization. Can short-circuit and reject invalid requests early, avoiding handler invocation and resource waste.

Available data: method, path, query, headers (body not yet parsed/available). To reject, set *reject_status to an HTTP error code (e.g., 401 Unauthorized, 403 Forbidden, 429 Too Many Requests) and return 0.

Parameters
reqRequest context with method, path, headers accessible.
reject_statusOutput: HTTP status code for rejection response. Ignored if allowing request (return non-zero). Server sends basic error response with this status.
userdataUser data set via SocketHTTPServer_set_validator().
Returns
Non-zero (true) to approve request and proceed to handler callback, 0 (false) to reject with the status in *reject_status (connection may close).
Note
Validator runs after initial parsing but before body handling; efficient for headers-only checks.
Multiple validators can be chained externally if needed, but server supports only one.
For per-endpoint validation, implement in handler or use rate limiting API.
Thread-safety: Called from event thread; ensure validator is reentrant if sharing state.
See also
SocketHTTPServer_set_validator() to register.
SocketHTTPServer_Request_headers() for header access in validator.
SocketHTTP_status_reason() for status code phrases.
Utilities Group for rate limiting integration.

Enumeration Type Documentation

◆ HTTP1_InternalState

enum HTTP1_InternalState

Low-level internal parser states for the DFA-based HTTP/1.1 parser.

These states drive the table-driven deterministic finite automaton (DFA) for efficient, single-pass parsing of HTTP/1.1 messages including request/response lines, headers, chunked bodies, and trailers.

Parsing flows:

  • Request: HTTP1_PS_START HTTP1_PS_METHOD HTTP1_PS_SP_AFTER_METHOD HTTP1_PS_URI HTTP1_PS_SP_AFTER_URI version states HTTP1_PS_LINE_CR HTTP1_PS_LINE_LF
  • Response: HTTP1_PS_START version states HTTP1_PS_STATUS_CODE HTTP1_PS_SP_AFTER_STATUS HTTP1_PS_REASON HTTP1_PS_LINE_CR HTTP1_PS_LINE_LF
  • Headers loop: HTTP1_PS_HEADER_START HTTP1_PS_HEADER_NAME HTTP1_PS_HEADER_COLON HTTP1_PS_HEADER_VALUE HTTP1_PS_HEADER_CR HTTP1_PS_HEADER_LF (repeat until HTTP1_PS_HEADERS_END_LF)
  • Chunked body: HTTP1_PS_CHUNK_SIZE states HTTP1_PS_CHUNK_DATA HTTP1_PS_CHUNK_DATA_CR HTTP1_PS_CHUNK_DATA_LF
  • Trailers: Similar to headers after final chunk.

Individual state descriptions provided in enum values.

See also
http1_char_class for character classification used in transitions.
http1_req_state, http1_resp_state for state transition tables.
http1_req_action, http1_resp_action for actions triggered by transitions.
RFC 7230 sections 3 (message format) and 4 (request/response) for grammar.
SocketHTTP1_Parser_execute() for how states are advanced.
SocketHTTP1.h for public parser interface.
HTTP/1.1 Module for group documentation.

◆ ServerConnState

enum ServerConnState

Internal states tracking the processing pipeline of a server connection.

State machine transitions:

  • CONN_STATE_READING_REQUEST CONN_STATE_READING_BODY (if content-length/chunked) CONN_STATE_HANDLING
  • CONN_STATE_HANDLING CONN_STATE_STREAMING_RESPONSE (if streaming response) CONN_STATE_SENDING_RESPONSE
  • CONN_STATE_SENDING_RESPONSE CONN_STATE_CLOSED or back to CONN_STATE_READING_REQUEST (keep-alive)

Used for timeout enforcement, logging, and resource cleanup.

See also
ServerConnection::state
SocketHTTPServer_Config for timeout configurations per state.

◆ URIParserState

enum URIParserState

Internal states for DFA-based URI parser (RFC 3986 compliant).

State machine states used by SocketHTTP_URI_parse() for parsing URI components: scheme://[userinfo@]host[:port]/path?query::fragment

Handles generic syntax including IPv6 literals, percent-encoding, and reserved chars. Invalid transitions lead to SocketHTTP_InvalidURI exception.

◆ http2_emit_conn_event()

void http2_emit_conn_event ( SocketHTTP2_Conn_T  conn,
int  event 
)
extern

Invoke registered connection event callback for notifications.

Calls the connection's conn_callback function if registered (non-null), passing the connection context, the event type (e.g., HTTP2_EVENT_SETTINGS_ACK, HTTP2_EVENT_PING_ACK, HTTP2_EVENT_GOAWAY_RECEIVED, HTTP2_EVENT_CONN_CLOSED), and the associated userdata. Includes null check on conn to safely skip if invalid. Emitted internally after significant connection-level events like settings negotiation complete, ping acknowledgments, GOAWAY receipt, or connection closure/ready states, allowing user code to monitor health, adjust configuration, or initiate failover. Synchronous direct call; no queuing.

Parameters
connThe HTTP/2 connection containing the callback registration (null-safe).
eventEvent identifier from HTTP2_EVENT_* constants (connection-specific).
Note
Immediate execution; user callback should not destroy the connection.
Fire-and-forget; callback return ignored.
Thread-unsafe: Direct access; protect with locks in concurrent use.
See also
SocketHTTP2_Conn::conn_callback and ::conn_callback_data for registration.
SocketHTTP2_ConnCallback typedef in SocketHTTP2.h for function signature.
http2_emit_stream_event() for stream-specific events.
Examples: emitted in http2_process_settings(), http2_process_ping(), http2_process_goaway().

Invoke registered stream event callback for notifications.

Calls the connection's stream_callback function if registered (non-null), passing the connection context, the affected stream, the specific event type (e.g., HTTP2_EVENT_HEADERS_RECEIVED, HTTP2_EVENT_DATA_RECEIVED, HTTP2_EVENT_STREAM_RESET, HTTP2_EVENT_WINDOW_UPDATE), and the associated userdata. Includes null checks on conn and stream parameters to safely skip invocation if invalid. Emitted internally after key stream lifecycle events like header decoding complete, data buffering, flow control updates, or error conditions, enabling user code to react (e.g., parse headers, forward data, retry logic). Synchronous direct call; does not queue events.

Parameters
connThe HTTP/2 connection containing the callback registration (null-safe).
streamThe stream associated with the event (null-safe).
eventEvent identifier from HTTP2_EVENT_* constants.
Note
Callback execution is immediate; user must avoid modifying conn/stream destructively.

Thread-unsafe: Direct state access; serialize if multi-threaded.

◆ http2_flow_adjust_window()

int http2_flow_adjust_window ( int32_t *  window,
int32_t  delta 
)
extern

Adjust flow control window by signed delta, typically from SETTINGS update.

Safely modifies a 32-bit signed window size, preventing underflow (negative) or overflow beyond INT32_MAX. Used when peer's INITIAL_WINDOW_SIZE setting change requires updating connection and all active stream windows.

Parameters
windowPointer to int32_t window value to modify (non-NULL).
deltaSigned integer delta (positive increase, negative decrease).
Returns
0 on successful adjustment, -1 if delta would cause invalid state.
Note
Logs debug info on clamping; may trigger flow control errors if extreme.
See also
http2_process_settings() for applying INITIAL_WINDOW_SIZE changes.
Thread Safety\n Yes - modifies only the caller-provided window value via pointer; no shared state or connection access, safe for concurrent calls on distinct windows
Complexity\n O(1) - simple arithmetic adjustment and bounds check
// Adjust stream window after SETTINGS change
int32_t stream_window = get_initial_window();
int32_t delta = new_setting - old_setting;
if (http2_flow_adjust_window(&stream_window, delta) == 0) {
// Apply to all active streams
for each stream {
stream->send_window += delta; // Already validated per-stream
}
conn->initial_send_window = new_setting;
} else {
// Log clamping or error
SOCKET_LOG_WARN_MSG("Window adjustment failed");
}

// Send a SETTINGS ACK frame

hdr.type = HTTP2_SETTINGS_FRAME;
hdr.flags = HTTP2_SETTINGS_ACK_FLAG;
hdr.length = 0;
hdr.stream_id = 0;

}
// Buffer queued; flush later via SocketHTTP2_Conn_process() or manual send

Validate an HTTP/2 frame header against protocol rules.

Performs comprehensive checks including frame length bounds, type-specific flags, stream ID validity (odd/even for client/server), dependency rules, and connection state constraints (e.g., no frames before preface verification).

Parameters
connThe HTTP/2 connection context (non-NULL).
headerPointer to frame header structure.
Returns

Note
Early validation prevents malformed frames from proceeding to payload processing.
Exceptions

Thread Safety\n No - reads connection state without internal synchronization; caller must ensure exclusive access to the connection object
Complexity\n O(1) - performs a fixed set of validation checks independent of input size
// Example: Validate frame header in frame reader loop
SocketHTTP2_ErrorCode err = http2_frame_validate(conn, &header);
if (err != HTTP2_NO_ERROR) {
SOCKET_LOG_WARN_MSG("Frame validation failed: %d", err);
http2_send_connection_error(conn, err);
return -1;
}
// Safe to process payload
int processed = http2_process_frame(conn, &header, payload);

◆ http2_process_continuation()

int http2_process_continuation ( SocketHTTP2_Conn_T  conn,
const SocketHTTP2_FrameHeader *  header,
const unsigned char *  payload 
)
extern

Process incoming HTTP/2 CONTINUATION frame to continue oversized header blocks.

Validates the frame occurs immediately after a HEADERS, PUSH_PROMISE, or previous CONTINUATION without END_HEADERS (checks expecting_continuation and stream_id match). Retrieves the target stream; failure or no pending header_block triggers PROTOCOL_ERROR GOAWAY. Enforces limit on CONTINUATION frames per header block to mitigate DoS floods (exceed -> GOAWAY ENHANCE_YOUR_CALM). Appends payload fragment to stream's accumulated header_block, validating total size <= MAX_HEADER_LIST_SIZE setting (exceed -> RST_STREAM ENHANCE_YOUR_CALM). Dynamically grows the temporary buffer if needed via arena allocation. If END_HEADERS flag set, finalizes the block: resets continuation state, decodes complete HPACK header block into stream's headers[] or trailers[] array (depending on context), emits headers event via stream callback, applies any pending END_STREAM from initial frame, and frees the temporary header_block. Supports split headers for large or compressed blocks.

Parameters
connThe HTTP/2 connection context (must be expecting CONTINUATION).
headerCONTINUATION frame header (type=CONTINUATION, stream_id=pending stream, flags=END_HEADERS or 0, length=fragment size; no padding/priority).
payloadRaw header block fragment bytes to append (HPACK compressed).
Returns
0 on successful append or complete processing/decode, -1 on validation, size exceed, or DoS detection (sends GOAWAY or RST_STREAM).
Precondition
Frame header validated by http2_frame_validate(); prior frame set continuation state.
Exceptions
SocketHTTP2_ProtocolErroron unexpected CONTINUATION or state mismatch.
SocketHTTP2_StreamErrorvia RST on size limits or stream issues.
Note
CONTINUATION must strictly follow without interleaving other frames for same stream.
Temporary buffer grown via arena; cleared after decode to free memory.
See also
SocketHTTP2_Conn::expecting_continuation, ::continuation_stream_id, ::continuation_frame_count.
SocketHTTP2_Stream::header_block, ::header_block_len for accumulation.
http2_decode_headers() invoked on END_HEADERS for HPACK decompression.
grow_header_block() for buffer expansion.
RFC 9113 Section 6.10 CONTINUATION Frames for sequencing and format.
RFC 9113 Section 4.3 Header Block Fragment for split handling rules.
RFC 9114 Section 4 for HPACK block processing after reassembly.

Main entry for processing a received HTTP/2 frame.

After header parsing and validation, dispatches to frame-type specific processor based on header->type. Handles common logic like stream lookup, state transitions, flow consumption, and error propagation (RST_STREAM or GOAWAY). Updates connection/stream states and may trigger callbacks.

◆ http2_process_goaway()

int http2_process_goaway ( SocketHTTP2_Conn_T  conn,
const SocketHTTP2_FrameHeader *  header,
const unsigned char *  payload 
)
extern

Process incoming HTTP/2 GOAWAY frame for connection shutdown notification.

Parses the GOAWAY payload to extract the highest stream ID the sender has processed successfully (last_stream_id, 31-bit unsigned) and the error code indicating the reason for initiating shutdown (e.g., NO_ERROR for graceful close, PROTOCOL_ERROR for issues). Updates connection state: sets goaway_received flag, records max_peer_stream_id to prevent new streams beyond this ID, and stores error code. Emits HTTP2_EVENT_GOAWAY_RECEIVED event via connection callback, allowing application to handle (e.g., close higher streams, retry elsewhere). Ignores frame header (pre-validated) and any optional debug data following the 8-byte fixed header fields in payload. Does not respond or alter other state.

Parameters
connThe HTTP/2 connection context.
headerGOAWAY frame header (type=GOAWAY, stream_id=0, length >=8).
payloadPayload: last_stream_id (4 bytes big-endian u31), error_code (4 bytes u32), optional variable-length debug data (ignored).
Returns
0 on successful parsing and state update (always succeeds post-validation).
Precondition
Frame header validated by http2_frame_validate().
Note
NO_ERROR (0) indicates graceful shutdown; non-zero codes signal errors affecting new streams.
Application must poll connection state or events to detect and react.
See also
SocketHTTP2_Conn::goaway_received, ::max_peer_stream_id, ::goaway_error_code for updated fields.
http2_emit_conn_event() for event notification.
http2_send_connection_error() for sending local GOAWAY.
RFC 9113 Section 6.8 GOAWAY for format, semantics, and error code details.
RFC 9113 Section 9.3 for HTTP/2 error handling and connection closure.

◆ http2_process_headers()

int http2_process_headers ( SocketHTTP2_Conn_T  conn,
const SocketHTTP2_FrameHeader *  header,
const unsigned char *  payload 
)
extern

Process incoming HTTP/2 HEADERS frame (pseudo-headers and HPACK decoding).

Decodes HPACK-compressed headers from payload, validates pseudo-headers (e.g., :method, :path), handles END_HEADERS and PRIORITY flags, updates stream state (may transition to OPEN or CLOSED). Applies header table size updates if SETTINGS_ENABLE_PUSH, emits headers event to callback. Handles CONTINUATION chaining for oversized headers.

Parameters
connHTTP/2 connection context.
headerParsed frame header (includes stream ID, flags, length).
payloadRaw frame payload bytes for HPACK decoding.
Returns
0 on success (headers decoded and applied), -1 on error (e.g., HPACK decode fail, invalid pseudo-header).
Precondition
Frame header validated, stream exists or valid for new stream.
Exceptions
SocketHTTP2_ProtocolErrorfor malformed headers or forbidden pseudo-headers.
SocketHTTP2_StreamErrorif stream state invalid for HEADERS.
See also
SocketHPACK_decode() for header decompression.
http2_frame_validate() pre-validation.
RFC 9113 6.3 HEADERS format and semantics.
RFC 7541 4.3 Pseudo-Header Fields for server/client rules.

◆ http2_process_ping()

int http2_process_ping ( SocketHTTP2_Conn_T  conn,
const SocketHTTP2_FrameHeader *  header,
const unsigned char *  payload 
)
extern

Process incoming HTTP/2 PING frame for connection liveness checks and timing.

Applies DoS protection by rate limiting PING frames within a sliding time window; exceeds limit triggers connection closure with ENHANCE_YOUR_CALM error. For frames with ACK flag, verifies the 8-byte opaque payload matches any outstanding ping request opaque data, clears pending state if matched, and emits HTTP2_EVENT_PING_ACK event via connection callback. For non-ACK PING frames (probes from peer), immediately responds by queuing a PING ACK frame echoing the same opaque payload for round-trip time measurement. PING frames are connection-level (stream_id must be 0) and do not affect flow control or streams.

Parameters
connThe HTTP/2 connection context.
headerPING frame header (type=PING, length=8, stream_id=0, flags=ACK or 0).
payloadFixed 8-byte opaque arbitrary data for correlation between request/ACK.
Returns
0 on successful processing (ACK queued or verified), -1 on rate limit exceeded or validation failure (sends GOAWAY via connection error).
Precondition
Frame header validated (fixed length 8, stream_id 0).
Exceptions
SocketHTTP2_ProtocolErrorindirectly if validation or state mismatch.
Note
Rate limiting uses monotonic timestamps; window reset on timeout.
Thread-safe: No - modifies connection state (use mutex if multi-threaded).
See also
SocketHTTP2_Conn::ping_count_in_window and ::ping_window_start_ms for limits.
http2_frame_send() for queuing ACK response.
http2_emit_conn_event() for PING_ACK notification.
RFC 9113 Section 6.7 PING Frames for protocol details and usage.
SocketHTTP2_Conn::ping_pending and ::ping_opaque for request/ACK matching.

Process incoming HTTP/2 PRIORITY frame for dependency tree updates.

Parses 4-byte stream dependency ID, weight (1-256), and exclusive flag. Updates stream's parent/weight/exclusive in priority tree, may rebalance scheduler. Valid only on open streams; ignores on idle/closed. No flow control impact.

Parameters

headerPRIORITY frame header (stream ID must be non-zero).
payloadFixed 5-byte payload: dep_stream_id (31 bits) + exclusive (1 bit) + weight (8 bits).
Returns
0 on success (priority updated), -1 if invalid (e.g., self-dependency, closed stream).
Precondition
Frame length == 5, header validated.
Exceptions

◆ http2_process_push_promise()

int http2_process_push_promise ( SocketHTTP2_Conn_T  conn,
const SocketHTTP2_FrameHeader *  header,
const unsigned char *  payload 
)
extern

Process incoming HTTP/2 PUSH_PROMISE frame for server push promise.

Handles server-sent PUSH_PROMISE frames on client side: validates receipt conditions (client role, push enabled in settings, associated stream open), extracts promised stream ID (must be even, unused), creates promised stream in RESERVED_REMOTE state marked as push, handles padding if flagged, initiates HPACK header block decoding into promised stream's headers, sets up CONTINUATION state if END_HEADERS not flagged, checks against MAX_HEADER_LIST_SIZE setting.

On failure (invalid promised ID, size exceed, etc.), sends RST_STREAM (REFUSED_STREAM) or triggers GOAWAY (PROTOCOL_ERROR). Successfully starts header decoding process.

Parameters
connThe HTTP/2 connection context (must be client role).
headerPUSH_PROMISE frame header (stream_id identifies associated open request stream).
payloadRaw payload: optional pad length (1 byte if PADDED), promised_stream_id (4 bytes), header block fragment, optional padding bytes.
Returns
0 on successful processing (stream created, decoding queued), -1 on error (connection/stream error sent, may lead to GOAWAY).
Precondition
Frame header validated by http2_frame_validate(); connection ready.
Exceptions
SocketHTTP2_ProtocolErrorvia http2_send_connection_error() on validation failure.
SocketHTTP2_StreamErrorvia RST if stream creation fails or limits exceeded.
Note
Server push only; servers ignore incoming PUSH_PROMISE.
See also
validate_push_promise() internal validation.
extract_push_promise_payload() payload parsing.
http2_stream_create() for promised stream allocation.
http2_decode_headers() for header block decompression.
SocketHTTP2_Conn::expecting_continuation for chaining support.
RFC 9113 Section 6.6 PUSH_PROMISE for format and semantics.
RFC 9113 Section 8.2 Server Push for usage and client control via settings.

◆ http2_process_window_update()

int http2_process_window_update ( SocketHTTP2_Conn_T  conn,
const SocketHTTP2_FrameHeader *  header,
const unsigned char *  payload 
)
extern

Process incoming HTTP/2 WINDOW_UPDATE frame to replenish flow control windows.

Deserializes the 31-bit unsigned window increment from the fixed 4-byte payload. Rejects increment == 0 as PROTOCOL_ERROR, sending GOAWAY (connection-level) or RST_STREAM (stream-level) accordingly. For connection-level updates (stream_id=0), applies increment to connection send window using http2_flow_update_send (NULL stream); arithmetic overflow or invalid state triggers GOAWAY with FLOW_CONTROL_ERROR. For stream-level (stream_id >0), retrieves stream via lookup; if found, updates both stream and connection send windows, emits HTTP2_EVENT_WINDOW_UPDATE via stream callback on success; failure sends RST_STREAM with FLOW_CONTROL_ERROR to that stream. Unknown or closed streams are silently ignored per RFC. This frame allows receiver to advertise additional data capacity after consuming buffered DATA, unblocking peer sends.

Parameters
connThe HTTP/2 connection context.
headerWINDOW_UPDATE frame header (type=WINDOW_UPDATE, length=4, stream_id=0 or stream ID).
payloadFixed 4-byte big-endian unsigned 31-bit increment (>0 required).
Returns
0 on successful update (or ignore for unknown stream), -1 on validation or update error (sends GOAWAY or RST_STREAM as appropriate).
Precondition
Frame header validated by http2_frame_validate().
Exceptions
SocketHTTP2_FlowControlErrorvia error frames on window update failure (e.g., overflow).
SocketHTTP2_ProtocolErrorfor zero increment.
Note
Updates affect http2_flow_available_send() immediately, potentially unblocking sends.
See also
http2_flow_update_send() for window arithmetic and validation.
process_connection_window_update() and process_stream_window_update() for dispatch logic.
http2_stream_lookup() for stream retrieval.
http2_emit_stream_event() for event emission on stream updates.
RFC 9113 Section 6.9 WINDOW_UPDATE Frames for details and rules.
RFC 9113 Section 6.9.2 Flow-Control Windows: receiving updates.
RFC 9113 Section 5.1 Stream States: window updates only on open/half-closed streams.

Compute Digest authentication response value.

Implements RFC 2617 Digest auth response calculation. Supports qop="auth", MD5 or SHA-256 algorithm. Computes HA1 = H({username:realm:password}), HA2 = H({method:uri}), response = H(HA1:nonce:nc:cnonce:qop:HA2). Outputs hex digest to buffer.

cnonceThe client nonce string.
use_sha2561 for SHA-256, 0 for MD5.
outputBuffer for hex response string.
output_sizeSize of output (33 for MD5, 65 for SHA256 + null).
Returns

◆ httpclient_pool_free()

void httpclient_pool_free ( HTTPPool *  pool)
extern

Dispose of HTTP connection pool and all associated resources.

Closes all open connections by calling Socket_free on each entry's socket, frees individual HTTPPoolEntry structures back to free list or arena, destroys hash table entries, clears statistics counters, and destroys mutex. Does not dispose or clear the underlying arena; caller must manage arena lifetime to avoid leaks of any remaining arena-allocated data. Handles partial failures gracefully (e.g. one connection close fail doesn't stop others).

Parameters
[in,out]poolPointer to HTTPPool (set to NULL after successful disposal).
Returns
void
Exceptions
None- socket close or mutex destroy failures are logged via SocketLog but not raised as exceptions.
Thread Safety\n Conditional - safe if no concurrent access to pool; acquire pool->mutex externally if shared.

Usage Example

// Typical paired with creation
HTTPPool *pool = httpclient_pool_new(arena, &config);
// ... use pool ...
httpclient_pool_free(pool); // Closes all conns, frees entries
pool = NULL; // Set to NULL per convention
Arena_dispose(&arena); // Finally dispose arena
Arena_dispose
void Arena_dispose(Arena_T *ap)

◆ httpclient_pool_new()

HTTPPool * httpclient_pool_new ( Arena_T  arena,
const SocketHTTPClient_Config *  config 
)
extern

Create and initialize a new HTTP connection pool.

Allocates the pool structure and hash table from the provided arena. Hash size computed from config max connections with security bounds to ensure efficient lookups while preventing excessive memory allocation or DoS via large configs. Security checks via SocketSecurity_check_multiply prevent overflow. Initializes mutex for thread safety and sets limits from config.

Parameters
[in]arenaMemory arena for allocating pool structures, hash table, and entries.
[in]configHTTP client configuration for sizing (max_total_connections, max_connections_per_host, idle_timeout_ms).
Returns
Pointer to new HTTPPool instance, ready for use.
Exceptions
SocketHTTPClient_Failedif arena allocation fails, config invalid (e.g. zero max), or mutex init fails.
Thread Safety\n No - intended for single-threaded initialization; concurrent calls may race on arena.

Usage Example

Arena_T arena = Arena_new();
SocketHTTPClient_Config cfg;
SocketHTTPClient_config_defaults(&cfg);
// Internally, SocketHTTPClient_new calls this:
HTTPPool *pool = httpclient_pool_new(arena, &cfg);
if (pool) {
// Use pool for connections
HTTPPoolEntry *entry = httpclient_pool_get(pool, "example.com", 443, 1);
// ...
httpclient_pool_release(pool, entry);
}
httpclient_pool_free(pool);
Arena_dispose(&arena);

◆ SocketHPACK_Decoder_decode()

SocketHPACK_Result SocketHPACK_Decoder_decode ( SocketHPACK_Decoder_T  decoder,
const unsigned char *  input,
size_t  input_len,
SocketHPACK_Header *  headers,
size_t  max_headers,
size_t *  header_count,
Arena_T  arena 
)
extern

Decode a complete HPACK header block into headers array.

Performs full decompression of an HPACK-encoded header block from HTTP/2 HEADERS or PUSH_PROMISE frames. Supports all HPACK representations: indexed headers, literal headers (with/without indexing), dynamic table updates. Single-pass decoding with validation against decoder config limits to prevent security issues like decompression bombs. Decoded headers include pseudo-headers (e.g., :method, :authority) and regular headers, preserving block order. Name and value strings are null-terminated and allocated from the arena for easy use.

Parameters
[in]decoderInitialized decoder with security configuration (max sizes, expansion ratio).
[in]inputPointer to the encoded HPACK header block data.
[in]input_lenNumber of bytes in the input buffer.
[out]headersPre-allocated array of SocketHPACK_Header to store decoded results.
[in]max_headersCapacity of headers array (safety limit against excessive headers).
[out]header_countPointer to receive the number of decoded headers written to array.
[in]arenaArena_T for allocating copies of header name and value strings.
Returns
SocketHPACK_Result indicating success or error:
  • HPACK_OK: Complete decode, header_count populated.
  • HPACK_INCOMPLETE: Partial input; call again with more data.
  • HPACK_ERROR_: Specific failure (e.g., HPACK_ERROR_INVALID_INDEX, HPACK_ERROR_HUFFMAN).
Exceptions
SocketHPACK_ErrorOn validation failures, limit violations, or decoding errors.
Arena_FailedIf string allocations exceed arena capacity.
Thread Safety\n No - modifies decoder state (table updates); requires external synchronization for shared use.

Basic Usage Pattern

// In HTTP/2 frame processing loop
SocketHPACK_Header headers[128]; // Reasonable max for most requests
size_t num_headers = 0;
const unsigned char *hpdata = frame->headers.payload;
size_t hplen = frame->headers.length;
TRY {
SocketHPACK_Result res = SocketHPACK_Decoder_decode(decoder, hpdata, hplen,
headers, 128, &num_headers, arena);
if (res == HPACK_OK) {
// Process headers
for (size_t i = 0; i < num_headers; ++i) {
if (headers[i].never_index) {
// Handle sensitive header (e.g., authorization)
}
// Convert to HTTP request/response as needed
}
} else if (res == HPACK_INCOMPLETE) {
// Buffer more data and retry (rare for complete frames)
} else {
// Protocol error; consider GOAWAY or connection close
SOCKET_LOG_ERROR_MSG("HPACK decode failed: %s", SocketHPACK_result_string(res));
RAISE(SocketHTTP2_ProtocolError);
}
} EXCEPT (SocketHPACK_Error) {
// Log and handle
} END_TRY;
RAISE
#define RAISE(e)
Raise an exception with current file and line information.

END_TRY

SocketHPACK_Result SocketHPACK_Decoder_decode(SocketHPACK_Decoder_T decoder, const unsigned char *input, size_t input_len, SocketHPACK_Header *headers, size_t max_headers, size_t *header_count, Arena_T arena)
Decode a complete HPACK header block into headers array.
SocketHPACK_Error
const Except_T SocketHPACK_Error
SocketHPACK_Error - General HPACK operation failure.
HPACK_INCOMPLETE
@ HPACK_INCOMPLETE
Definition SocketHPACK.h:212
HPACK_OK
@ HPACK_OK
Definition SocketHPACK.h:211

Error Codes and Recovery

Code Typical Cause Recommended Action
HPACK_ERROR_INVALID_INDEX Invalid table index Peer error; send RST_STREAM or GOAWAY
HPACK_ERROR_HUFFMAN Corrupt Huffman codes/padding Validate peer; close connection
HPACK_ERROR_TABLE_SIZE Invalid size update > max Protocol violation; reject update
HPACK_ERROR_HEADER_SIZE Single header exceeds limit Increase config or drop oversized
HPACK_ERROR_LIST_SIZE Total size exceeds limit Increase config or truncate headers
HPACK_ERROR_BOMB Excessive expansion ratio Tighten max_expansion_ratio; ban peer IP

Security Considerations

  • Configurable limits prevent DoS via large headers or table updates.
  • max_expansion_ratio guards against "HPACK bombs" where encoded is small but decoded huge.
  • never_index flag respected for sensitive headers (e.g., cookies, auth).
  • Table size updates limited per block (SOCKETHPACK_MAX_TABLE_UPDATES).
Note
On success, *header_count <= max_headers; array not null-padded.
Pseudo-headers must appear before regular headers per RFC; order preserved.
Supports Huffman decoding with padding validation (max 7 trailing 1-bits).
Partial decodes (HPACK_INCOMPLETE) advance internal state; resume with more input.
Arena strings lifetime ends with arena clear/dispose; copy if needed longer.
Warning
Always validate *header_count before accessing headers array.
Do not reuse headers array across calls without clearing or size check.
In production, log and monitor error rates for HPACK_ERROR_* codes.
Complexity\n O(n + m) where n=input size, m=output headers (linear scan + allocations)
See also
SocketHPACK_Decoder_new() for creating secure decoders
SocketHPACK_DecoderConfig for limit tuning
SocketHPACK_Header for output structure details
SocketHPACK_result_string() to get human-readable errors
SocketHTTP2.h for HTTP/2 frame integration
docs/SECURITY.mdHPACK Header Compression Module-Security Modules for attack mitigations
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7541#section-6 for decoding spec

◆ SocketHPACK_Table_free()

void SocketHPACK_Table_free ( SocketHPACK_Table_T *  table)
extern

Dispose of a dynamic table instance and release its resources.

Safely frees the dynamic table, returning all allocated memory to the arena. The table pointer is set to NULL to prevent use-after-free errors.

This function does not throw exceptions as it performs no allocations. It is safe to call on already-NULL pointers (no-op).

Parameters
[in,out]tablePointer to the dynamic table instance. Set to NULL on success.
Thread Safety\n No - caller must ensure no concurrent access to the table or arena.

Usage Example

Arena_T arena = Arena_new();
TRY {
SocketHPACK_Table_T table = SocketHPACK_Table_new(SOCKETHPACK_DEFAULT_TABLE_SIZE, arena);
// ... use table for encoding/decoding ...
} EXCEPT(SocketHPACK_Error) {
// Handle error
} FINALLY {
SocketHPACK_Table_free(&table);
} END_TRY;
Arena_dispose(&arena);
FINALLY
#define FINALLY
Define cleanup code that executes regardless of exceptions.

SOCKETHPACK_DEFAULT_TABLE_SIZE
#define SOCKETHPACK_DEFAULT_TABLE_SIZE
Default dynamic table size in bytes (RFC 7541 default).
Definition SocketHPACK.h:124

Important Notes

  • Always pair with SocketHPACK_Table_new() using the same arena for lifecycle management.
  • No individual header strings are freed; they remain in the arena until Arena_clear() or Arena_dispose().
  • In multi-threaded environments, synchronize access to shared arenas.
Note
This operation does not iterate over table entries; memory is managed by the arena.
Warning
Failing to free tables can lead to arena exhaustion and memory leaks.
Complexity\n O(1) - constant time operation
See also
SocketHPACK_Table_new() for table creation
Arena_dispose() for complete resource cleanup
SocketHPACK_Encoder_free() and SocketHPACK_Decoder_free() for related cleanup patterns
docs/HTTP.md for HTTP/2 header compression overview

◆ SocketHPACK_Table_new()

SocketHPACK_Table_T SocketHPACK_Table_new ( size_t  max_size,
Arena_T  arena 
)
extern

Create a new dynamic HPACK table for header compression.

Initializes a dynamic table used for storing header fields to reduce redundancy in HTTP/2 header blocks (RFC 7541). The table supports eviction of least recently used (oldest) entries when size limits are reached, using a circular buffer for efficiency. All internal allocations (entries, strings) are arena-managed for fast cleanup.

Parameters
[in]max_sizeMaximum allowed size for the table in bytes. Includes SOCKETHPACK_ENTRY_OVERHEAD (32 bytes) per entry. Must be 0 <= max_size <= SOCKETHPACK_MAX_TABLE_SIZE. Default recommendation: SOCKETHPACK_DEFAULT_TABLE_SIZE (4096).
[in]arenaArena_T instance for all memory allocations. Table lifetime is bound to this arena.
Returns
Opaque pointer to new dynamic table instance.
Exceptions
SocketHPACK_ErrorIf max_size invalid or internal initialization fails.
Arena_FailedIf arena allocation fails (propagated).
Thread Safety\n Yes - atomic creation; arena must be synchronized if shared across threads.

Basic Usage

Arena_T arena = Arena_new();
SocketHPACK_Table_T table = NULL;
TRY {
table = SocketHPACK_Table_new(SOCKETHPACK_DEFAULT_TABLE_SIZE, arena);
assert(table != NULL);
// Table ready for use in encoders/decoders
} EXCEPT(Arena_Failed, SocketHPACK_Error) {
fprintf(stderr, "Failed to create table: %s\n", Except_message(Except_stack));
return -1;
} END_TRY;
// Use table...
SocketHPACK_Table_free(&table);
Except_stack
Except_Frame * Except_stack
Thread-local exception stack for TRY/EXCEPT/FINALLY blocks.
Arena_Failed
const Except_T Arena_Failed
Exception raised when arena allocation fails.

Advanced Configuration

max_size Value Recommended For Expected Entries Compression Impact
0 Minimal memory 0 No dynamic compression
4096 (default) General use ~10-20 Good balance
16384 High-volume HTTP/2 ~50-100 Better ratios
65536 (max) Servers ~200+ Optimal but memory-intensive
Note
Table starts empty (size=0, count=0). Populate during encoding or manually.
Strings added to table are copied into arena; originals can be freed after.
Use with SocketHPACK_Encoder_new() or SocketHPACK_Decoder_new() for HTTP/2.
Warning
Large max_size increases memory footprint; monitor with SocketHPACK_Table_size().
Never pass NULL arena; will raise Arena_Failed.
Complexity\n O(1) - constant time initialization and allocation
See also
SocketHPACK_Table_free() for paired cleanup
SocketHPACK_Table_add() to populate with headers
SocketHPACK_Table_set_max_size() for dynamic resizing
SocketHPACK_Encoder_new() for encoder integration
Arena.h for memory management details
docs/HTTP-REFACTOR.md for performance tuning
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7541#section-4 for RFC specification

◆ SocketHPACK_Table_set_max_size()

void SocketHPACK_Table_set_max_size ( SocketHPACK_Table_T  table,
size_t  max_size 
)
extern

Update the maximum size of the dynamic table.

Changes the dynamic table's maximum capacity, potentially evicting the oldest entries to fit within the new limit. This operation is typically triggered by a HTTP/2 SETTINGS frame updating HEADER_TABLE_SIZE. Entries are evicted from the oldest (highest index) until the table size is <= max_size.

Parameters
[in]tableThe dynamic table instance to update.
[in]max_sizeNew maximum table size in bytes, including overhead per entry. Must be >= 0 and <= SOCKETHPACK_MAX_TABLE_SIZE.
Exceptions
SocketHPACK_ErrorIf max_size is invalid (negative or exceeds maximum allowed).
Thread Safety\n No - concurrent updates or accesses may lead to inconsistent state or data races.

Usage Example

SocketHPACK_Table_T table = ...; // Initialized table
// Increase for better compression
TRY {
SocketHPACK_Table_set_max_size(table, 16384); // 16KB
} EXCEPT(SocketHPACK_Error) {
SOCKET_LOG_ERROR_MSG("Failed to update table size: %s", Socket_GetLastError());
}
// Reduce size, evicting if necessary
SocketHPACK_Table_set_max_size(table, 2048); // 2KB
Socket_GetLastError
const char * Socket_GetLastError(void)
Socket_GetLastError - Retrieve the most recent formatted error message.
SocketHPACK_Table_set_max_size
void SocketHPACK_Table_set_max_size(SocketHPACK_Table_T table, size_t max_size)
Update the maximum size of the dynamic table.

Eviction Behavior

Condition Action
new_size >= current_size No eviction
new_size < current_size Evict oldest entries until compliant
new_size == 0 Clear entire table

Query After Update

After calling, verify with:

  • SocketHPACK_Table_size(table) <= max_size
  • SocketHPACK_Table_max_size(table) == max_size
Note
Affects compression efficiency; larger tables improve ratios but use more memory.
Synchronized between encoder/decoder via SETTINGS frames in HTTP/2.
Warning
Frequent size changes can cause unnecessary evictions and performance overhead.
Complexity\n O(n) worst case - linear in number of entries if full eviction needed
Complexity\n O(1) average - if no or few evictions
See also
SocketHPACK_Table_new() for initial configuration
SocketHPACK_Table_size() to get current usage
SocketHPACK_Table_count() for entry count changes
SocketHPACK_Decoder_set_table_size() for decoder synchronization
SocketHPACK_Encoder_set_table_size() for encoder updates
docs/HTTP.mdHPACK Header Compression Module-dynamic-table for HTTP/2 specifics

◆ SocketHPACK_Table_size()

size_t SocketHPACK_Table_size ( SocketHPACK_Table_T  table)
extern

Query the current size of the dynamic table in bytes.

Returns the total size of all entries in the dynamic table, including the 32-byte overhead per entry as per RFC 7541 Section 4.1. This value represents memory usage and is always <= the maximum table size set via SocketHPACK_Table_set_max_size().

Parameters
[in]tableThe dynamic table instance to query.
Returns
Current table size in bytes (sum of name/value lengths + SOCKETHPACK_ENTRY_OVERHEAD * entry count).
Thread Safety\n No - concurrent table modifications (add/evict) may cause inconsistent return values.

Usage Example

SocketHPACK_Table_T table = SocketHPACK_Table_new(4096, arena);
size_t size = SocketHPACK_Table_size(table); // Initially 0
// After adding entries
SocketHPACK_Table_add(table, ":method", 7, "GET", 3);
size = SocketHPACK_Table_size(table); // ~42 bytes (value + name + overhead)
printf("Table size: %zu bytes\n", size);
SocketHPACK_Table_size
size_t SocketHPACK_Table_size(SocketHPACK_Table_T table)
Query the current size of the dynamic table in bytes.
SocketHPACK_Table_add
SocketHPACK_Result SocketHPACK_Table_add(SocketHPACK_Table_T table, const char *name, size_t name_len, const char *value, size_t value_len)
Add entry to dynamic table.

Size Calculation

Total size = \sum (name_len + value_len) + (count * SOCKETHPACK_ENTRY_OVERHEAD)

Component Description
Header Data Sum of all name and value string lengths
Overhead 32 bytes per entry for indexing and metadata
Note
Size does not include static table; only dynamic entries.
Returns 0 for empty table.
Complexity\n O(1) - maintained incrementally during add/evict operations
See also
SocketHPACK_Table_count() for entry count
SocketHPACK_Table_max_size() for capacity limit
SocketHPACK_Table_add() for adding entries that increase size
SocketHPACK_ENTRY_OVERHEAD for per-entry cost
docs/HTTP-REFACTOR.mdHPACK Header Compression Module-memory-management for tuning advice

◆ sockethttp_hash_name()

static unsigned sockethttp_hash_name ( const char *  name,
size_t  len 
)
inlinestatic

Hash HTTP header name for case-insensitive bucket lookup.

Parameters
namePointer to null-terminated or length-bounded header name bytes.
lenExact byte length of name (excluding null if present).
Returns
Computed hash modulo SOCKETHTTP_HEADER_BUCKETS (0-30).
Thread Safety\n Yes - pure function, no side effects or shared state.

Implements case-insensitive DJB2 hash variant: folds input to lowercase during hashing for consistent header name bucketing per RFC 9110. Designed for low collision rate with typical HTTP headers.

◆ SocketHTTP_header_value_valid()

int SocketHTTP_header_value_valid ( const char *  value,
size_t  len 
)
extern

Validate header value.

Parameters
valueHeader value
lenValue length
Returns
1 if valid (no NUL/CR/LF), 0 otherwise
Thread Safety\n Yes

SECURITY: Rejects NUL, CR, and LF characters to prevent HTTP header injection attacks (CWE-113). Per RFC 9110 Section 5.5, obs-fold (CRLF followed by SP/HTAB) is deprecated and should not be generated.

This stricter validation prevents:

  • CRLF injection for header manipulation
  • Response splitting attacks
  • Cache poisoning via injected headers
  • Session hijacking via injected Set-Cookie

◆ SocketHTTP_URI_parse()

SocketHTTP_URIResult SocketHTTP_URI_parse ( const char *  uri,
size_t  len,
SocketHTTP_URI *  result,
Arena_T  arena 
)
extern

Parse and validate a URI string into components.

Parameters
uriInput URI string (absolute or relative reference).
lenLength of URI (0 to use strlen(uri)).
[out]resultPointer to SocketHTTP_URI structure to populate.
arenaArena for allocating parsed string components (must outlive result).
Returns
URI_PARSE_OK on success, or specific error code on failure.
Exceptions
Arena_Failedif memory allocation for components fails.
SocketHTTP_InvalidURIon invalid URI syntax, malformed components, or validation failures (e.g., invalid host, port out of range).
Thread Safety\n Yes, if arena is thread-safe or thread-local.

Parses URI per RFC 3986 generic syntax, supporting absolute URIs, origin form, and relative refs. Validates scheme, host (including [IPv6]), port, path, query, fragment. Rejects overly long URIs (> SOCKETHTTP_MAX_URI_LEN) and invalid characters. IPv6 hosts must be in RFC 3986 bracketed form. Does not percent-decode; components retain original encoding (use SocketHTTP_URI_decode()). Userinfo parsed but flagged as deprecated. Path is always non-NULL (empty for no path).

Note
Result strings point into arena-allocated memory or input buffer substrings.

◆ SocketHTTPServer_config_defaults()

void SocketHTTPServer_config_defaults ( SocketHTTPServer_Config *  config)
extern

Initialize SocketHTTPServer_Config with safe default values.

Populates the configuration structure with production-ready defaults:

  • port: 8080
  • bind_address: "0.0.0.0"
  • backlog: 128
  • max_header_size: 64KB
  • max_body_size: 10MB
  • timeouts: 30s request, 60s keepalive/write
  • limits: 1000 connections, 100 per client, etc.
  • TLS: NULL (HTTP)
  • HTTP/2 upgrade: disabled

Customize fields after initialization before passing to SocketHTTPServer_new(). Validates basic config sanity (e.g., positive limits) but does not bind/test.

Parameters
configPointer to configuration structure to initialize. Must not be NULL; contents overwritten.
Thread Safety\n Yes - pure function, no side effects or shared state.
Note
Defaults can be overridden at compile-time via #defines (e.g., HTTPSERVER_DEFAULT_PORT).
See also
SocketHTTPServer_new() which consumes this config.
SocketHTTPServer_Config for field details and ranges.

Referenced by main().

◆ SocketHTTPServer_drain()

int SocketHTTPServer_drain ( SocketHTTPServer_T  server,
int  timeout_ms 
)
extern

Initiate graceful server shutdown by draining active connections.

Transitions server to DRAINING state: closes listening socket (no new accepts), allows in-flight requests/connections to complete naturally via timeouts or finish(). After specified timeout (or infinite), force-closes any remaining to STOPPED. Integrates with poll/process loop; call drain_poll() or drain_wait() to monitor. Signals OS/epoll to stop queuing new SYNs if possible.

Parameters
serverServer instance (running state).
timeout_msMax ms to wait for graceful completion (-1=infinite, 0=immediate force).
Returns
0 if drain started successfully, -1 on error (already stopped/draining).
Note
Existing connections: requests handled, but no new on them after start.
Timeout triggers abrupt close (possible data loss for unfinished responses).
Call before free() for clean shutdown; drain_wait() for blocking.
Stats preserved; errors during drain logged/incremented.
See also
SocketHTTPServer_drain_poll() to check progress in loop.
SocketHTTPServer_drain_wait() blocking convenience.
SocketHTTPServer_state() to query current state.
SocketHTTPServer_set_drain_callback() for completion notification.
docs/SIGNALS.md "Graceful Shutdown" for signal integration.
Thread Safety\n No - changes server state globally.
Exceptions
SocketHTTPServer_Failedif internal timer/setup fails.

◆ SocketHTTPServer_drain_poll()

int SocketHTTPServer_drain_poll ( SocketHTTPServer_T  server)
extern

Non-blocking check of drain progress and remaining work.

Queries number of active connections during DRAINING: polls internal pool/timer. Returns count of connections needing completion (processing or idle but open). Call in event loop (with process()) until 0 (complete) or -1 (timed out, force-closed). Complements drain_wait() for custom loops or integration.

Parameters
serverServer in DRAINING (ignore otherwise).
Returns
>0 active connections remaining, 0 fully drained (STOPPED soon), -1 drain timed out (force-close triggered, state STOPPED).
Note
Decreases as requests finish/connections idle-timeout.
Call frequently during drain; pairs with process() for progress.
On -1, remaining connections closed abruptly (possible aborted requests).
Callback invoked on 0 or -1 transition.
See also
SocketHTTPServer_drain() initiates draining.
SocketHTTPServer_drain_wait() blocking wrapper using this.
SocketHTTPServer_state() alternative state query.
SocketHTTPServer_Stats.active_connections cross-check.
docs/SIGNALS.md for poll in signal handlers.
Thread Safety\n No - snapshots internal counts, may race.

◆ SocketHTTPServer_drain_remaining_ms()

Calculate remaining time before drain timeout forces connection closure.

Returns ms left until DRAINING state force-closes lingering connections. Uses monotonic clock for accuracy; accounts for elapsed since drain start. 0 indicates immediate force-close imminent or already STOPPED. Useful for logging warnings or client notifications during shutdown.

Block until graceful drain completes or times out.

Convenience function to wait for drain process: repeatedly calls process(0) and drain_poll() until STOPPED or timeout. Handles the loop internally. Uses provided timeout or falls back to drain() timeout if -1. Non-blocking alternative: manual loop with drain_poll().

After return, server STOPPED; safe to free().

◆ SocketHTTPServer_free()

void SocketHTTPServer_free ( SocketHTTPServer_T *  server)
extern

Dispose of HTTP server instance and release all resources.

Closes listening socket, frees connection pool, timers, internal buffers, and arena allocations. Any ongoing requests are aborted and connections closed abruptly (no graceful drain). Call SocketHTTPServer_stop() or SocketHTTPServer_drain() first for clean shutdown.

Sets *server to NULL on success. Idempotent: safe to call on NULL or already-freed server.

Parameters
serverPointer to server instance (set to NULL after free). Must not be NULL.
Exceptions
SocketHTTPServer_Failedon internal cleanup errors (rare).
Thread Safety\n No - concurrent access to server undefined; use mutex if multi-threaded.
Warning
Does not wait for in-flight requests; data loss possible if called mid-process.
Note
TLS contexts are not freed (referenced only).
See also
SocketHTTPServer_drain_wait() for graceful shutdown before free.
SocketHTTPServer_stop() to halt without full cleanup.
Arena_T for memory management details.

Referenced by main().

◆ SocketHTTPServer_process()

int SocketHTTPServer_process ( SocketHTTPServer_T  server,
int  timeout_ms 
)
extern

Main event loop step: poll, accept, parse, handle requests.

Performs a single iteration of the internal event loop:

  • Polls registered fds (listening socket + client connections + timers) for timeout_ms.
  • Accepts new connections up to configured limits (rate, per-IP).
  • Reads/parses incoming data on connections (HTTP/1.1 or 2 frames).
  • Invokes validator and handler for complete requests.
  • Writes pending responses, applies flow control (HTTP/2).
  • Cleans up idle/timeout connections.
  • Triggers drain callback if applicable.

For continuous operation, call in loop with timeout -1 (infinite, interruptible). For integration, use smaller timeouts or external poll with SocketHTTPServer_fd().

Parameters
serverRunning server (started via SocketHTTPServer_start()).
timeout_msMaximum wait time in ms (-1 = infinite/block until event).
Returns
Number of requests fully processed (handler invoked + response sent), or -1 on fatal error (raises exception).
Exceptions
SocketHTTPServer_ProtocolErroron malformed requests.
SocketHTTPServer_Failedon I/O or internal errors.
Thread Safety\n No - advances shared server state.
Note
Returns early on timeout even if events pending; call repeatedly.
For high performance, tune SocketPoll via SocketHTTPServer_poll().
Metrics updated internally; query with SocketHTTPServer_stats().
See also
SocketHTTPServer_poll() for low-level poll access.
SocketHTTPServer_fd() for hybrid external/internal loop.
Event System for polling backend details.
Socket_get_monotonic_ms() for timing consistency.

Referenced by main().

◆ SocketHTTPServer_Request_begin_stream()

int SocketHTTPServer_Request_begin_stream ( SocketHTTPServer_Request_T  req)
extern

Initiate a streaming (chunked) response to the client.

Starts the response by sending status and headers with Transfer-Encoding: chunked (or equivalent HTTP/2 frames). Enables sending body in arbitrary chunks without knowing total length upfront. Ideal for dynamic content generation, large files, or real-time data (e.g., SSE, progress updates). Headers sent immediately; subsequent send_chunk() append body chunks. Must follow with end_stream() to finalize (sends trailers if any).

Parameters
reqRequest context (headers/status must be set prior).
Returns
0 on success (headers sent, ready for chunks), -1 on failure.
Note
Do not call status(), header(), body_data(), body_string(), or finish() after.
Chunk size unlimited per call, but internal buffers apply (8KB typical).
Client must support chunked (HTTP/1.1 default); HTTP/1.0 may fail.
For HTTP/2, translates to multiple DATA frames with end-stream flag on last.
Warning
No Content-Length set; clients buffer until end_stream().
See also
SocketHTTPServer_Request_send_chunk() to emit body chunks.
SocketHTTPServer_Request_end_stream() to finalize and close body.
SocketHTTP1_chunk_encode() low-level chunk formatting.
RFC 9112 Section 7.1 for chunked encoding spec.
docs/HTTP.md "Streaming Responses" for examples.
Thread Safety\n No - commits response, modifies connection state.
Exceptions
SocketHTTPServer_Failedon immediate send failure (e.g., closed conn).

◆ SocketHTTPServer_Request_finish()

Finalize the response and transmit it to the client.

Serializes the configured status, headers, and body into an HTTP message and sends it over the connection. For non-streaming responses, full body sent. Updates server stats (bytes sent, latency, error counters if fails).
Warning

◆ SocketHTTPServer_Request_push()

int SocketHTTPServer_Request_push ( SocketHTTPServer_Request_T  req,
const char *  path,
SocketHTTP_Headers_T  headers 
)
extern

Initiate an HTTP/2 server push of a related resource to the client.

Sends a promised PUSH_PROMISE frame followed by pushed response (HEADERS + DATA). Allows server to preemptively send resources likely needed by client (e.g., CSS/JS for HTML). Only functional on HTTP/2 connections; HTTP/1.x returns -1 (no push support). Client may refuse (via RST_STREAM); check return for success. Path relative to request URI authority; full URL constructed internally.

Parameters
reqRequest context on HTTP/2 stream.
pathTarget resource path (e.g., "/style.css"; relative).
headersOptional headers for pushed request (method GET assumed; :method can override).
Returns
0 if push initiated successfully, -1 if failed/unsupported (not HTTP/2, client refused, error).
Note
Push streams consume window/bandwidth; use judiciously to avoid DoS.
Client settings (e.g., ENABLE_PUSH=0) or GOAWAY may disable.
Pushed responses still subject to server config limits/timeouts.
Warning
Over-pushing harms performance; base on Cache-Control, Link headers.
See also
SocketHTTPServer_Request_is_http2() to check protocol support.
SocketHTTP2_Stream for low-level push control.
RFC 9113 Section 6.6 "Server Push" for specification.
docs/HTTP.md "HTTP/2 Server Push" for usage patterns.
Thread Safety\n No - allocates push stream on connection.
Exceptions
SocketHTTPServer_ProtocolErrorif HTTP/2 frame errors.

◆ SocketHTTPServer_Request_upgrade_websocket()

SocketWS_T SocketHTTPServer_Request_upgrade_websocket ( SocketHTTPServer_Request_T  req)
extern

Accept WebSocket upgrade and switch protocol.

Performs WebSocket handshake: sends 101 Switching Protocols response with Sec-WebSocket-Accept key, then returns opaque WebSocket_T handle for framing. Transitions connection from HTTP to WebSocket (ws:// or wss:// over TLS). After upgrade, use SocketWS APIs for messages, close, etc.; HTTP functions invalid. Request context and HTTP state discarded post-upgrade.

Parameters
reqRequest context with valid upgrade request (is_websocket() true).
Returns
SocketWS_T instance for WebSocket operations, or NULL on failure (e.g., invalid handshake).
Note
Validates client key, computes accept value per RFC 6455.
Sec-WebSocket-Protocol negotiated if offered (config or first).
TLS remains active if HTTPS (becomes wss://).
Warning
Connection now WebSocket-only; no revert to HTTP.
Note
Metrics: upgrades counted in stats; errors logged.
See also
SocketHTTPServer_Request_is_websocket() to check before upgrade.
SocketWS_T and group__websocket for WebSocket API.
RFC 6455 "The WebSocket Protocol" for handshake spec.
docs/WEBSOCKET.md "Upgrading from HTTP" for examples and config.
Thread Safety\n No - switches connection state, consumes req.
Exceptions
SocketHTTPServer_ProtocolErroron handshake validation failure.
SocketHTTPServer_Failedon response send error.

Referenced by request_handler().

)
extern

Register the primary request handler callback and associated user data.

Sets the callback invoked for every valid HTTP request after parsing and validation. Previous handler (if any) is replaced. NULL handler disables request handling (server accepts but immediately closes connections with 500).

Userdata is stored and passed unchanged to every invocation of handler. Can be changed dynamically; affects future requests only.

Parameters
serverServer instance (must be created but not required to be started).
handlerCallback function or NULL to disable handling.
userdataOpaque pointer passed to handler on each request.
Thread Safety\n No - updates shared server state.
Note
Handler must be thread-safe if server uses multi-threaded poll (advanced).
Set before starting or processing to avoid missing requests.
For dynamic routing, implement path/method logic inside handler.
See also

SocketHTTPServer_Validator for pre-handler middleware.
HTTP Group for request/response types.
